title: Modern Web Design Vocabulary
description: Categorized design language tokens mapped to the design ontology schema.

tokens.definition: A 12-column system with uneven content weighting to create directional focus.
A repeatable card lattice with consistent gutters and row cadence.
Hero section divided into two dominant zones, typically message and visual.
One primary text rail optimized for long-form narrative scanning.
Deliberate horizontal misalignment that creates tension and visual pacing.
Large section-to-section spacing cadence to increase hierarchy clarity.
Spacing increments quantized to 8px multiples for consistency.
Intentional alternation between dense and airy zones across sections.
Surrounding priority content with empty space to increase salience.
Periodic full-bleed sections used to reset visual momentum.
The first viewport is controlled by one large headline or message block.
Early placement of evidence elements before detailed feature content.
Narrative progression from pain point framing to product resolution.
Alternating section treatments to sustain scanning and reduce monotony.
Persistent conversion zone that remains visible through key scroll ranges.
Large geometric sans headline optimized for impact and modern tone.
Reduced letter spacing on headlines to increase visual density.
Body type with tall lowercase forms for improved screen legibility.
Intentional size jump between display and support copy for hierarchy.
Headline style mimicking editorial quote emphasis rather than slogan tone.
Primary display family paired with a distinct supporting body family.
Defined progression of font weights across headline, subhead, and body.
Generous leading to support readability in text-heavy sections.
Small uppercase labels used for metadata or section framing.
Tabular numeral usage to align metrics and comparison data.
Near-black foundation used for high contrast and visual restraint.
Low-glare light background with slight warmth for editorial tone.
Alternating foundational tones to segment narrative chapters.
Low-saturation base colors that foreground content over decoration.
Preserving strong contrast moments only for priority interactions.
Bright synthetic accent used sparingly for focal emphasis.
Soft gradient spread with low saturation and limited footprint.
Semi-transparent panel with blur and subtle edge highlight.
Soft, broad shadowing that suggests elevation without harsh edges.
Thin border treatment to define surfaces in low-contrast palettes.
Minimal elevation cues with emphasis on color and spacing separation.
Clear z-axis hierarchy through cards, overlaps, and shadow gradation.
Depth defined primarily by translucent surfaces and blur effects.
Combination of flat and elevated components by interaction priority.
Low-opacity atmospheric texture that adds depth without distraction.
Elements appear with upward translation and delayed sequencing on scroll.
Section boundary transitions that signal narrative progression.
Background and foreground layers move at different scroll rates.
Pinned content region synchronized with stepwise scroll states.
Reduced-motion mode that removes transforms but preserves sequencing cues.
Short hover animation increasing size slightly with eased deceleration.
Cursor-proximate motion attracting call-to-action elements.
Subtle elevation and shadow increase on pointer hover.
Interactive border luminance increase to confirm affordance.
Fast interactions with minimal dwell and quick settle timing.
Order-focused layout tradition emphasizing alignment and hierarchy.
Content-led aesthetic with restrained visual ornament and strong type.
Contemporary product aesthetic using synthetic accents and controlled glow.
Deliberate rawness through stark contrast, rigid shapes, and minimal polish.
Style grouping centered on clean structure with focused technical cues.
Reject animations that do not communicate state or improve usability.
Reject high-intensity gradients that reduce text legibility.
Reject inconsistent visual language shifts without narrative rationale.
Reject size systems where priority content and support copy converge.
Reject palette choices that erode text or interaction readability.
